li.p: Taking stock of the A-series approach

subsection.heading: 1 Introduction
subsection.p: The foundational issues for a correct account of temporal talk in natural language appear uncontentious: we exploit an ontology countenancing temporal entities (time points, time intervals, and/or events) to serve as the referents of such phrases as at three, when John arrived, etc., and of the variables appearing in temporal quantification: often, always, seldom, etc. Those entities are organized in a natural sequence by the earlier-than/later-than relation, which also turns out to be useful to account for our intuitions about the meaning of tenses – e.g., ‘past’ contributes that the relevant event/time is before the speech/utterance time – and of such phrases as John left after his sister entered. The resulting temporal structures seem so natural and intuitive that linguists almost never question them. All we have to do is to use it to discover how temporal reference is managed by language.

However, another view about time in language (and time in general) has exercised scholars for years, originating from concerns expressed by philosophers. According to its proponents, we can, and actually must, dispense with temporal entities, hence with temporal reference. Our temporal talk cannot be analyzed on the model of objectual talk by positing temporal entities ordered by the earlier-than/later-than relation, which, e.g., Thursday or May can draw their reference from, or which tenses relate. The correct approach, it is maintained, requires taking the very idea of tensed thoughts/propositions seriously, meaning that the latter are intrinsically tensed and that tense cannot be explained away by means of precedence.

Though not popular among linguists, such a view has been recently revived and sharpened by Ludlow (1999), who proposes a view that strikingly differs not only from ‘strictly’ referential approaches, but from those based on so-called temporal logics too.

Preference for one over the other account has profound effects on linguistic theory. In the one case, we expect to avail ourselves of the machinery made available to semantics and syntax by the referential view, which includes objectual quantification, referential anaphora, and the referential view of indexicality. If the other path is followed, many of those tools are useless, and something new must be devised. The differences are not limited to semantics, but involve syntax. If we execute the non-referential approach by means of temporal operators for tenses, then de re/de dicto distinctions become crucial. Those, in turn, are usually taken to rely on syntactic operations, which interact with many other such devices, so that evidence in favor or against can be gathered and assessed on syntactic grounds. Similarly, we will see that the two views exploit different syntactic structures for temporal locating phrases such as next May or the Sunday you left.

The purpose of this chapter is to stimulate a critical attitude toward issues of temporal reference in linguistic theory, discuss the two alternative views, and start some comparative work. In a way, it is about time to do so. Ludlow's attempt at making the non-referential, tensed view play a role in the linguistic arena makes it possible to lay down, compare, and discuss the prospects of actual proposals. At the same time, the present work cannot aim at exhausting the comparative work. The difference between the two approaches in terms of available analyses and effort spent by scholars is too big to permit fair comparative assessments. We will be content if a picture emerges which highlights relative weaknesses and strengths of the two views, and if topics to be inserted in the research agenda can be found.

We will proceed as follows. In section 2 we provide a cursory review of the basic tenets of the tense-logical approaches. These have the interesting property of exemplifying many of the problems non-referential views have to address, despite the fact that they still rely on ontology of time points, intervals, and the likes. The shortcomings of tense-logical theories have been taken to provide support for fully referential views, which will be the topic of section 3, where phenomena such as the syntax of tenses, sequence of tense, and temporal locating phrases will be discussed. Special emphasis will be placed on the Reichenbachian and on the neo-Reichenbachian view. In section 4 we turn to the non-referential, tensed view, by presenting Ludlow's proposal in some details. To facilitate comparisons, we will focus on the same set of phenomena discussed in section 3, investigating how they can be dealt with in a tensed framework.

subsection.heading: 2 Tenses as sentential operators
subsection.p: Tense logical approaches to time in natural language (cf. Prior 1967; Montague 1974) consider tenses as sentential operators, which apply to basic (untensed) sentences to yield other, tensed sentences. Semantically, they shift the evaluation time of a sentence to the past or to the future. In the cases we are going to consider, the evaluation time always coincides with the time of the utterance, symbolized by u.
Consider the following examples:

(1)
a. John saw Mary.
b. P[see(John, Mary)]

(2)
a. John will see Mary.
b. F[see(John, Mary)]

The logical form for (1a) is (1b), where P is the operator for past. Analogously, in the case of a future tense verb (will see), the operator is F. A possible model for this logic is a triple M = (T, <, V) where T is a set of moments of time, < is the binary relation earlier than on T, and V is the interpretation function which assigns a truth-value Vt(&phis;) to each propositional formula &phis; and to a moment of time t∈T. The relevant truth-conditions for the operators P and F are given in (3a) and (3b), respectively:

(3)
a. VM, t (P&phis;) = true iff there is t′, t′<t and VM, t’ (&phis;) = true.
b. VM, t (F&phis;) = true iff there is t′, t<t′ and VM, t’ (&phis;) = true.

That is, P&phis; is true at the evaluation time t with respect to a model M iff there is a time t′ which is past with respect to t, and &phis; is true at t′ with respect to M. Analogously, F&phis; is true at the evaluation time t, with respect to a model M iff there is time t′ which is in the future with respect to t, and &phis; is true at t′ with respect to M. Applying (3) to (1) and (2), we obtain (4):

(4)
a. VM, t (P(‘John see Mary’)) = true iff there is t′, t′<t and VM, t′ (‘John see Mary’) = true.
b. VM, t (F(‘John see Mary’)) = true iff there is t′, t<t′ and VM, t′ (‘John see Mary’) = true.

That is, John saw Mary is true at a time t iff there is a time t′ which precedes the time of the utterance and the untensed proposition ‘John see Mary’ is true at t′. On the other hand, John will see Mary is true when uttered at a time t iff there is a future time t′ such that p=’John see Mary’ is true at t′. As can be seen from (3), both F and P have an existential flavor, in that their truth-conditions require the existence of a time at which the proposition they apply to is true. Classical Priorean tense logic also includes the corresponding universal operators G and H, where G&phis; can be paraphrased as ‘in the future it will always be the case that &phis;’, and H&phis; as ‘in the past it has always been the case that &phis;’.

Importantly, tense operators can be combined to yield more complex configurations. Such a possibility has been exploited to capture the meaning of compound tenses such as the English pluperfect, which could be seen as the composition of two past operators, PP, and of the future perfect, represented as PF.

The tense operator approach has been criticized from both an empirical and a theoretical point of view. We will consider some of these criticisms, namely those discussed by Enç (1986), and others arising from observations originally made by Kamp (1968).
If tenses are operators, we expect them to exhibit scope properties analogous to those of other operators and quantified expressions, such as DPs. Consider (5) (cf. Enç 1986: ex. 3):
(5) All rich men were poor children.
The meaning of (5) can be paraphrased as in (6):
(6) All rich men (past and present ones) were at a previous time poor children.
The logical forms for (5) are given in (7):

(7)
a. ∀x (rich-man(x) ∧ P(poor-child(x)))
b. P(∀x (rich-man(x) ∧ poor-child(x)))

The verb were instantiates a past operator P. Furthermore, in (5) the universally quantified DP all rich men appears. Given that operators manifest scope properties, we expect the temporal operator P to interact with the quantified DP, each possibly taking scope on the other. Consider the case where the universal quantifier has wider scope, thus yielding (7a). The corresponding proposition is true iff for every presently rich man x there is a past time at which x is a poor child. This is not the meaning of (5), according to our intuitions, because it takes into account only presently rich men. If we let the tense operator take scope over the universal operator, (7b) is obtained, a proposition which is true iff there is a past time t such that every man who is rich at t is also a poor child at the same past time. Again, we are far from the meaning of (5) as expressed by (6). Thus, both scope possibilities fail to capture (5), and it seems that a standard account of the scope interactions of a tense operator with quantified expressions does not suffice to obtain the correct result (for more recent work about the temporal properties of noun phrases, see Musan 1995).

It also has been observed that tense operators introduced by verbal morphology are not sufficient to account for some interpretive facts. Consider, for example, the following sentence (Enç 1986: ex. 13):
(8) Every fugitive is now in jail.
The operator approach assigns (8) the following meaning:
(9) Every x who is now a fugitive is presently in jail.
Example (8), however, is an assertion about past fugitives who are presently in jail. The correct truth-conditions are exemplified by (10):
(10) ∀x ((P(fugitive(x))) ∧ in-jail(x))

To obtain (10), it must be assumed that the past tense operator P is instantiated by the subject DP. Notice in fact that the verbal tense is present and therefore cannot be the verb which instantiates the operator. Moreover, the scope of the operator should not include the predicate and should be restricted to the subject. Generally, however, tense operators are introduced by tense morphemes related to the verbs and have the predicate in their scope. In (8) and similar cases, there is no such past tense morpheme – that is, there is no morphosyntactic evidence of its presence and there is no obvious way to constrain the scope of this operator to the DP. In principle, in fact, an operator associated with the DP could take scope over the whole sentence. In this case we would obtain (11):
(11) ∀x (P(fugitive(x) ∧ in-jail(x)))

Example (11) is true iff everyone who was a fugitive at a past time was in jail at the same time. Again, such a reading is not the correct one. Therefore the hypothesis according to which DPs introduce tense operators does not make the correct predictions, because the scope properties of such operators are anomalous and should be constrained by means of ad hoc conditions. Consider also that if it were correct to hypothesize the presence of an operator taking scope over the DP, we should also investigate the scope relations between two DPs, each bearing its own temporal interpretation (and, consequently, its own tense operator). In particular, when a DP is c-commanded by another one, we would expect the temporal interpretation of the former to depend on the temporal interpretation of the latter. Consider the example in (12) (modeled on Enç 1986: ex. 8):
(12) Every student will have met a president.

A possible reading of (12), which is the one relevant to our discussion, is the following: let us hypothesize a scenario where every present student either met, or is meeting, or will meet at a future time the president in charge at that moment. Sentence (12) is true at the utterance time if there is a later time at which every student met a president is true. In this scenario, the DP every student is evaluated at the present time, whereas a president can be evaluated at a past, present, or future time. That is, the times relevant for the two DPs must be kept separate, so that the temporal interpretation of the DP a president does not depend on the interpretation of the DP every student, even if a president is in the scope of the latter. As a consequence, the expectation that tense operators introduced by DPs exhibit the scope properties of ordinary quantified expressions is not met.

To summarize, tense operators introduced by DP do not take scope over the main predicate, as shown by (10), and they do not interact with each other, as shown by our discussion of (12). If we still want to maintain the hypothesis that a DP can be associated with a tense operator, we should constrain such a tense operator to take only very local scope, because it seems to have only the DP itself in its scope. As we said in the preceding discussion, this move is possible, but requires a rather ad hoc hypothesis.
Another argument against the use of tense operators comes from the analysis of the interactions between tenses in complex sentences. Consider (13), due to Kamp (1968):

(13)
a. A child was born who would be king.
b. A child was born who will be king.
(14) P(∃x (child(x) ∧ born(x) ∧ F(king(x))))

The sentences in (13a) and (13b) differ only in the use of two different future forms in the relative clause; namely, the auxiliary would vs. will. The logical form in (14) represents the meaning of (13a). The future tense operator, introduced by the verb of the relative clause, is in the scope of the tense operator of the main verb. Formula (14) is then true iff there is a past time t at which a child was born and there is a time future with respect to t when it is true that the child is king. Thus, (14) correctly captures the meaning of (13a). On the other hand, it is not so easy to account for the meaning of (13b), the version in which the simple future, will, appears in the relative clause. Formula (14) does not work, for (13b) requires the time at which the child is said to be king to be in the future with respect to the utterance now, something which is not made available by (14). There is an alternative option; namely, that the future operator takes scope over the matrix clause past operator, yielding (15):
(15) FP(∃x (child(x) ∧ born(x) ∧ king(x)))

Formula (15), however, is not a correct representation of (13b) either, since it requires a future time t and a time t′, t′ < t, such that born(x) and king(x) are both true at t′. What is needed for (13b) is the possibility for the two tenses to be independently evaluated with respect to the utterance time. Tense logic, however, cannot represent the two operators as being independent from each other.

The examples in (13) raise a problem very similar to those discussed by Enç. One major inadequacy of the tense operator approach seems to be that the interactions among the temporal properties of the constituents of a sentence are not the ones expected for tense operators. In other words, an operator-based representation is insufficient to account for the temporal interpretation of the sentences considered above.

Another problem with the tense logical approach is the possibility of compounding the basic operators F and P to yield more complex ones. On the one hand, languages like English have tenses that seem to be naturally analyzable by means of such a property. For instance, the pluperfect and the future perfect could correspond to PP and FP, respectively. On the other hand, there are compound tenses that resist a similar treatment. For example, the present perfect cannot be straightforwardly distinguished from the simple past by virtue of operator compositions.

Another problem is that nothing prevents an unlimited composition of tense operators. Any sequence is a priori possible – e.g., FPF, PPP, FPFP, etc. – even if none of them corresponds to an observable tense in any language. The composition of operators could be constrained by means of ad hoc conditions, for instance, by explicitly disallowing combinations of more than two operators. This move, however, weakens the explanatory adequacy of the temporal logic approach.
Finally, tense logical approaches have notorious problems with the treatment of temporal anaphora. Consider (16) and (17):
(16) John left the room. He was furious.
(17) John said that Mary was pregnant.

In (16) the second sentence is understood as holding at the same time as the first. Example (17), on the other hand, can either mean that Mary's pregnancy holds at the time of John's utterance, or that the pregnancy is at an earlier time. Thus, both in (16) and (17) there seems to be a dependency of the time of the second clause (he was furious and Mary was pregnant) on the time of another clause.

The operator approach cannot easily account for the facts in (16) and (17). Anaphoric phenomena, in fact, seem to require the availability of entities, such as times and events (but also ordinary individuals referring to spatial objects), which can be introduced in the discourse context, stored, and accessed for later reference. No natural notion of context is possible with tense logic, unless major changes are proposed, undermining the spirit of these logical systems (for a discussion, see Kamp and Reyle 1993). Furthermore, although tense logic does make use of temporal entities, it does so at the level of the metalanguage, in the truth-conditions for operators. Hence, there are no terms referring to temporal entities in the object language (cf. the logical forms given above). This way of encoding the temporal dimension was motivated by considerations about verbal tenses, since their intrinsic relational meaning can be captured by means of truth-conditions such as those in (3), repeated here for simplicity:

(18)
a. VM, t (P&phis;) = true iff there is t′, t′<t and VM, t′ (&phis;) = true.
b. VM, t (F&phis;) = true iff there is t′, t<t′ and VM, t′ (&phis;) = true.

Verbal tense, however, is not the only manifestation of time in natural languages, and there are cases in which direct reference to temporal entities seems to be needed. Apparently, this is the case of temporal anaphora, as seen, and presumably also of temporal adverbials such as at four, yesterday, and so on. There are, therefore, many cases where direct reference to times appears to be necessary.

subsection.heading: 3 Temporal entities
subsection.p: In the previous section we have shown that (i) the temporal properties of sentences cannot be easily accounted for by means of the scopal dependencies among temporal operators; (ii) the compositional character of temporal operators does not provide an upper limit to the number of temporal operators which can be combined to yield tenses, failing therefore to explain the limited variety of tenses found in natural languages; and (iii) tense logic does not provide an account of temporal anaphora and of certain expressions that seem to require the availability of terms referring to times. All these considerations seem to favor a referential approach – that is, an approach that allows temporal reference directly in the object language, thus permitting an analysis of tenses, and temporal adverbials as referring (or involving reference) to temporal entities. Before turning to more details about the referential approach, let me emphasize that the basic opposition between the temporal logic approach and the so-called referential one is linguistic, not ontological-metaphysical. That is, both admit the reality of times (points, intervals, or whatever) with their usual properties (precedence). The difference is in the logical language: in one case, terms referring to those entities are exploited; in the other, reference to times is relegated to the metalanguage. As we will see, there is a more radical option, which expunges times from all levels of the logical language, prohibiting reference thereto tout court.

Before we continue, let us point out that we will often cast our consideration in a truth-theoretic semantic framework, inspired by the work of Higginbotham (1991) and Larson and Segal (1995). For obvious reason, there is no space here to discuss the approach in any detail, and the interested reader is referred to the publications cited. For our purposes, it suffices to say that the theory uses a ternary relation Val, between an entity, x, a linguistic object, Σ, and an assignment sequence, Val(x, Σ, σ), signaling that x is a value for Σ under assignment σ, and that this will be the basic building block for our semantic work.

We start by considering how tenses can be accounted for in a referential approach. The simpler possibility is to have them introduce relations between temporal entities; e.g., the past tense states that the time of the event precedes the time of the speech. Or, alternatively, that the event talked about in the clause precedes the speech/utterance event. Syntactically, tense morphemes are of category T, project a constituent TP, and take VP complements. Hypothesizing that both the latter are predicates of events, we could write the following axioms for T:

(19)
a. Val(e, Past, σ) iff e<u
b. Val(e, Pres, σ) iff e ° u
c. Val(e, Fut, σ) iff e>u

They say that, for a given assignment sequence σ, the value of a tense morpheme is event e iff such an event precedes the utterance (past tense), overlaps the utterance (present tense), or follows the utterance (future tense). The event is provided by the VP, and the combination of the tense with that phrase is ruled by the following axiom:
(20) Val(e, [TP T VP], σ) iff Val(e, VP, σ) and Val(e, T, σ)

This axiom says that event e is a value of [TP T [VP ran]] iff e is the value of the VP and of the node T. The axiom for the relevant tense, (19b), eventually constraints the event to precede the utterance.

It has been observed that this simple picture is not easy to extend to compound tenses. To this end, it might be worth considering the work done in the Reichenbachian tradition, starting from Reichenbach (1947). In this perspective, the correct temporal interpretation of tenses requires three temporal entities, not just two, adding the so-called reference time/event, r, to the already-seen event (time) and utterance (time). With this, tenses are devices ordering the three temporal entities. For example, the meaning of the present tense could be represented as u°r°e, stating that the event (time) overlaps the reference time/event, and the latter overlaps the utterance.

The Reichenbachian model has been adopted and revised by several linguists (among others, Comrie 1976a, 1985b; Vikner 1985b; Hornstein 1990; Scorretti 1991; Declerck 1986; Giorgi and Pianesi 1997). As already suggested by Reichenbach and then further discussed by Comrie (1985b) and Hornstein (1990), for both empirical and theoretical reasons it has been proposed that the relation among the three points be split into two distinct relations, one between r and u, and the other between e and r. The result is a system in which a direct relationship between e and u is never realized, but is always mediated by r. The possible relations are the following:

(21)
Type 1 relation
Type 2 relation
u>r future e>r perfect
r>u past r>e prospective
u°r present e°r neutral

As a consequence, the various tenses are the result of the composition of a relation of type 1, with a relation of type 2. For instance, according to this picture, the representation of the present tense is the result of the combination of u°r with e°r, to yield u°r°e. The representation of the present perfect is the result of the combination of u°r with e>r, to yield e>r°u. From the point of view of the final representation, this proposal exhibits an important empirical difference with respect to the original Reichenbach one. The point, often discussed in the literature (see Comrie 1985b and Hornstein 1990), concerns the future perfect. Such a tense results from the combination of u>r and e>r. Comrie points out that in English (and in Italian as well), a sentence such as (22) is ambiguous in three ways:
(22) John will have finished his manuscript by tomorrow.

The exact temporal relation between the finishing of the manuscript and the utterance is unknown. It could be that when the sentence is uttered, John has already finished the manuscript; or that he is finishing it exactly at that moment; or that he will finish after the utterance and before tomorrow. This ambiguity is nicely captured by the following combination of type 1 and type 2 relations:

As pointed out by Comrie and then by Hornstein, the revised Reichenbachian framework presents several other advantages over the original one. According to the latter, in fact, we would in principle expect the existence of languages where for each possible position of e, there is a morphologically different realization. In other words, Reichenbach predicts the existence of languages in which the meanings corresponding to u>e>r, u°e>r, e>u>r are expressed by means of different morphological tenses. Comrie points out that this does not seem to be the case.

Also, we have a way to account naturally and elegantly for the limited number of morphologized tenses, a problem that plagued the tense operator approach of the previous section. The system is based on three primitive objects plus binary relations. As such, the possibilities of combining the various forms are very limited. Finally, as pointed out by Hornstein (1990), such a system can be easily acquired, satisfying therefore an important requirement for any theory of tense. The inventory of resulting tenses is the following (the list is basically Hornstein's (1990: 117) with the addition of the distant future):

(24)
Present: u°r ∧ e°r = u°r°e
Past: r>u ∧ e°r = e°r>u
Future: u>r ∧ e°r = u>r°e
Present perfect: u°r ∧ e>r = e>r°u
Future perfect: u>r ∧ e>r
Past perfect: u>r ∧ e>r = e>r>u
Future in past: r>u ∧ r>e
Proximate future: u°r ∧ r>e = u°r>e
Distant future: u>r ∧ r>e = u>r>e

subsection.heading: 3.1 The syntax of tense
subsection.p: Given the revised Reichenbachian framework reviewed in the previous section, the possibility arises that the two types of relations between temporal entities correspond to two Tense head, T1 and T2, realizing type 1 and type 2 relations, respectively. Such a distinction can be motivated by showing that the morphemes realizing T1 and T2 have different contents, in terms of features and different morphosyntactic behaviors, and that this predicts the legitimate combination of these two categories, hence of available tenses.

This possibility has been pursued in Giorgi and Pianesi (1997), where it is proposed that tenses are doubly represented in clausal structure because of the existence of two projections, T1 and T2, with T1 higher than T2. For example, a compound tense such as the Italian or English past perfect (e.g., had eaten) or future perfect (will have eaten) would correspond to (at least) the following structure:

Here, T1 introduces the relation between the utterance and the reference point, whereas T2 takes care of relating the latter to the event. The lower VP is projected by the verb, whereas the higher one is projected by the auxiliary. AGR1 represents the set of phi-features, e.g., person and number, that are shared with the subject, i.e., (Spec, AGR1″). AGR2 can be specified for gender and number features, as in Italian. Giorgi and Pianesi hypothesize that there are no Ø tense heads, and that the representation for an Italian present tense form is the following:

(26)
a. Mangio.
eat-1sg
I eat.
b.

No T1 or T2 node is projected, and the meaning usually associated with the present tense results from a default process directly relating the event (introduced by the verb) and the utterance, yielding u°e. The idea is that, tenses being a semi-lexical category, they are present in syntax only if morphological evidence is available. In other cases, only T1 is projected, as in the Italian simple past:

(27)
a. Mangiai.
ate-1sg
I ate.
b.

Here T1 directly relates the event (introduced by the verb) to the utterance, yielding e>u. Finally, the present perfect is as in (28). T2 is projected, and connects the event to the reference time/event, giving e>r. T1, on the other hand, is absent, since the auxiliary is in the present tense. As before, this triggers a default interpretation according to which the reference event overlaps the utterance. This way we obtain the expected result: e>r°u.

(28)
a. Ho mangiato.
have-1sg eaten
I have eaten.
b.

As can be seen, Giorgi and Pianesi assign a bi-clausal structure to complex tenses, and treat the contribution of T1 and T2 in essentially the same manner. A past tense, be it expressed by T1 or T2, places the (entity corresponding to the) variable instantiated by the complement of the tense node before another entity (the reference time/utterance event). The lower clause is responsible for relating the event (time) and the reference time/event. The upper clause handles the latter variable, relating it to the utterance. This can be captured as follows:

(29)
a. Val(<x, y>, T2, σ) iff rel(x, y) where rel is >, <, or ° depending on whether T2 is past, future, or present.
b. Val(y, [T2P T2 VP], σ) iff Val(<x, y>, T2, σ) and Val(x, VP, σ).
c. Val(y, [VP Aux T2P], σ) iff Val(y, T2P, σ).
d. Val(z, T1, σ) iff rel(z, u), where rel is >, <, or ° depending on whether T1 is past, future, or present.
e. Val(z, [T1P T1 VP], σ) iff Val(z, T1, σ) and Val(z, VP, σ).

We have avoided using the variables e and r in (29) to stress the strong symmetry between the two tenses. Thus, when T2 is realized by a past tense morpheme, (29a) and (29b) jointly ensure that the value of T2P be an entity (the reference event) that is before the entity introduced by the VP (the event). Moreover, if T1 is a future morpheme, then the value of T1P is the entity realized by the VP, the latter turning out to be the same as the value of the embedded T2P. As before, the indexical nature of T1 tenses is handled directly by axiom (29d).

Those axioms provide a simple treatment of the second variable (the reference time/event). A more detailed account should accommodate the fact that it can draw its reference from the contexts, or be bound by a quantificational expression, as in:

(30)
Ogni volta che l’ho incontrato, Mario aveva parlato con il capoufficio.
every time that I him have met, Mario had spoken with the boss
‘Every time I met him, Mario had spoken with his boss.’

The variable corresponding to r can be both a temporal entity – a time point or interval – and an eventuality, according to the framework adopted. The second possibility enables us to introduce considerations about consequent states, a là Parsons (1990). The first alternative can be used to accommodate within this theory insights relying on the notion of an extended now, as in Dowty (1979). Finally, notice that in this approach the three Reichenbachian points lose any privileged status and become a side effect of the interplay between the syntactic and the semantic properties of tense morphemes, and the structures they enter into.

Other authors have elaborated on the idea of bi- (and even multi-) clausal structure for tenses. Thus Julien (2001) proposes that simple sentences involve both a TP-past and a TP-future, the former taking the second as its complement, and the latter the VP. Both T-past and T-future can have ±values:
(31) [TP-past T-past[± past] [TP-future T-future[±future] [VP]]]

When T-past has [+past] and T-future has [−future] the result is a simple past. Vice versa, if T-past is [−past] and T-future is [+future], we have a simple future. The present tense results from a configuration where both features have the value −, and, as in Giorgi and Pianesi, the relevant interpretation is the result of a default process. Finally, Julien admits the possibility that both features have a + value, exemplifying this possibility with the English future in the past would. This structure is extended to complex tenses by duplicating the structure below the auxiliary in (31). Other proposals in this direction can be found in Cinque (1999). For a partially different view, see Stowell (1996).

subsection.heading: 3.2 Sequence of tense
subsection.p: Up to now, our discussion of the referential theory has been limited to tenses in matrix clauses. In complement clauses, especially when predicates of propositional attitude are involved, tenses behave in peculiar ways, giving rise in languages such as English to so-called Sequence of Tense (SOT) phenomena. Thus, an utterance of (32) can be understood as reporting either a present tense utterance of John's – e.g., Mary is ill – or a past tense utterance – e.g., Mary was ill:
(32) John said/believed that Mary was ill.
Within the approach under discussion here, the backward-shifted reading can be captured by assigning (32) the following truth-conditions:
(33) ∃e(saying(e) ∧ Agent(e, John) ∧ Theme(e, ψ) ∧ e<u)
Here, ψ is the ILF for the subordinate clause with the following truth-conditions:
(34) ∃e′ (ill(e) ∧ Theme(e′, Mary) ∧ e′<e)
Once the two are put together we have:
(35) ∃e(saying(e) ∧ Agent(e, John) ∧ Theme(e, []∃e′ (ill(e) ∧ Theme(e′, Mary) ∧ e′<e)[]) ∧ e<u)

What is important here is that the truth-conditions for the subordinate clause explicitly mention the episode of saying, letting the tense relate it to the embedded eventuality (the illness); see Higginbotham (1995) for more on this topic. This establishes a parallel between the role the matrix eventuality – the subject's attitude episode – plays in the subordinate clause and the role played by the utterance in the matrix. In both cases, the tokening of an expression by an agent is used as a temporal coordinate from which the tense's contribution is computed. This parallel can be further pursued, as in Giorgi and Pianesi (2001a, 2001b), to account for the lack of mere indexical readings of tenses in subordinate clauses. Thus, (36) cannot be used to mean that John said something concerning the very time (36) is uttered – that is, the speech time – nor can (32) be used to report a dictum concerning events which are located in the past only with respect to the utterer – e.g., yielding a report which is future-oriented with respect to John:
(36) Last week John said that Mary is pregnant.

It seems, therefore, that whenever there is a tokening of a linguistic expression (as in matrix clauses), or a report about such a tokening (as in subordinate contexts), the temporal coordinates of the tokener must be explicitly given and connected to the event the expression is about. In other words, the ILF representing the object of a propositional attitude must explicitly represent the attitude episode itself, and use it to locate the talked-about event:

row.entry: A clause is the object of an attitude by a subject iff the ILF of that clause contains the subject temporal egocentric coordinate.
The primary role of tense is to locate the event with respect to such a coordinate.
The temporal coordinate of the subject is the attitude's episode itself.

subsection.p: Principle (37) correctly predicts that tenses in subordinate contexts cannot be mere indexicals, for that would amount to linking the event to the utterance, hence to the speaker's coordinate, violating (37). Moreover, it dissolves the notion of temporal anchoring (cf. Enc 1987) into the more general requirement that the contents of propositional attitude explicitly represent the attitude episode itself. Finally, it suggests that the assignment sequences that are used to compute the interpreted logical forms of clauses subordinated to verbs of propositional attitude had better be relativized to subjects. By this we mean that in the backward-shifted reading, the was of (32) is evaluated as if it were the subject's (John's) was, hence relating the state of illness to his coordinate – i.e., the saying/thought – rather than to the speaker's – i.e., the utterance. We do not discuss here how this idea can be implemented, for which we refer the reader to Giorgi and Pianesi (2001b). Suffice it to say that the availability of subject-oriented assignment sequences provides for the desired truth-conditions (33) and (35).
Turning to the simultaneous reading of (32), it can be given the following truth-conditions:
(38) ∃e(saying(e) ∧ Agent(e, John) ∧ Theme(e, []∃e′ (ill(e) ∧ Theme(e′, Mary) ∧ e′°e)[]) ∧ e<u)

They are consistent with the discussion above and with (37): the ILF of the subordinate clause explicitly represents the subject's temporal coordinate, and the tense relates this to the event. As before, this is obtained by computing the ILF of the subordinate clause by means of a subject-oriented assignment. With respect to the other reading, however, the well-known problem arises of how to accommodate the fact that an embedded past tense of (32) behaves as if it were a present tense. Roughly speaking, the explanations provided by the literature are of two different kinds. According to one view, the embedded past tense is only ‘apparent’ in (32); one might argue, in fact, that it is present during part of the derivation, but then disappears at LF, because of some deletion process obtaining in past-under-past contexts. Another view maintains that the past tense morpheme was not present during the derivation, and got inserted only as a by-product of spell-out. Both views share the idea that the LF representation for a (32) can have a Ø tense morpheme (or no tense morpheme at all), which interpretively yields – e.g., through some default mechanism – simultaneity. This approach was quite popular some times ago. More recently, it has been exploited by Ogihara (1995), though it has lost some of its appeal because it requires postulating mechanisms (deletion and/or insertion) that are not so readily available any more.

Another tradition has it that the past tense is morphologically present, but can be interpretively transparent, either because the embedded past tense enters some kind of agreement process with the matrix one, or because it acts as a scope marker for the matrix tense, or some similar mechanism. A recent proposal in this direction is that advanced by Abusch (1997). She hypothesizes that superordinate tenses can place constraints on subordinate ones, and that, vice versa, subordinate tenses inherit restrictions from superordinate ones. Thus she speaks of a local relation together with transmitted ones. In the case of a past-under-past sentence, the constraint is that at least one of these relations taken together (the local and transmitted ones) is temporal precedence. More precisely, she assumes that:

(39)
a. Tenses come with a relational variable relating their index to the local evaluation time.
b. Verbs such as believe transmit the relation associated with their tenses to their clausal complements, through a feature-passing mechanism. Hence embedded tenses have access to all the relations associated with higher tenses.
c. The semantic of tense is a constraint on the set of all available relations. For the past, the constraint is that at least one of them be precedence.

Given this, the simultaneous reading of (32) follows: (i) the constraint on the subordinate past tense is satisfied by the inherited precedence relation, and (ii) this makes it possible to understand the embedded event as simultaneous to the saying.

Another possibility is that pursued by Stowell (1996), who draws a parallel between tenses in subordinate contexts and polarity items. In his view, the past tense is a past-polarity item, meaning that if in the scope of another past tense it behaves as anybody in the scope of negation; both do not contribute anything to the interpretation, so that it becomes possible to understand the illness in (32) as simultaneous to the saying. It should be noticed that the actual implementation of both proposals is somewhat underspecified. Abusch's theory of transmitted relation relies on a feature-passing mechanism that is not easy to accommodate within current generative grammar frameworks. Stowell's view, on the other hand, suffers the same shortcomings as any treatment of polarity – namely, what is the underlying syntactic mechanism? In this sense both are somewhat stipulative, as is Schlenker's (2003a) recent proposal of agreement between semantic indices.

subsection.heading: 3.3 The double access reading
subsection.p: Together with some syntactic facts discussed in Giorgi and Pianesi (2000), principle (37) provides an account of double access sentences (DAR) – e.g., (36). As first observed by Smith (1978), such a sentence has the peculiarity that the pregnancy state referred to in the subordinate clause is simultaneous both to the saying and to the utterance. This doesn't mean that by using (36) a speaker commits herself to the truth of the complement – that is, to the existence of a pregnancy of Mary's holding at the speaker's time. Nor is there any commitment to the truth of the complement clause at Mary's, the subject's, time. Indeed, the speaker can continue her speech by uttering:
(40) Actually, he was wrong. Mary has just been overeating for the last three months.

Scholars such as Abusch (1997) and Ogihara (1995) have argued in favor of a de re analysis of tenses in these cases, hypothesizing that the embedded present tense gets scoped out in (36), and that both the tense and its trace contribute to the interpretation. Scoping out is obligatory in present-under-past contexts, because the constraint on local and inherited relation for the present tense is that none of them be temporal precedence (Abusch 1997), or because the present tense is an anti-past polarity item (Stowell 1996).

Once scoped out, the behavior of the present tense is analyzed within a framework built upon Lewis's (1979) suggestions, as further elaborated by Cresswell and Von Stechow (1982). In this view, for a subject X to have a de re belief about an object Y is for X to ascribe Y a certain property Z. Property ascription, in turn, relies on subject X being suitably connected with object X by means of an appropriate acquaintance relation which makes the object (epistemically) available to the subject. Omitting details (which can be found in the works cited), the analysis of a DAR sentence such as (36) requires that:

In Abusch's account, the first point follows from the already-mentioned theory of transmitted relations in intensional contexts: the constraint on the local and the transmitted relations of a present tense, in fact, is that none of them be temporal precedence. Thus, in a present-under-past sentence the tense must be scoped out. Finally, Abusch argues that a suitable acquaintance relation for (36) is one picking out the maximal interval at which Mary has a big belly (the hypothesis is that the speaker is interested in explaining Mary's symptoms), and one which, for independent reasons, picks up an interval that in the actual world overlaps with both the saying and the utterance time.

As should be clear, the offered account of the DAR relies on hypotheses involving both the syntax and the semantics. Concerning the former, it is necessary that the de re tense be scoped out of the embedded clause at LF, hence that a position be made available for it to land in. At the same time, the trigger for such a movement, though spelled out in terms of the constraints on local and transmitted relations, is essentially syntactic: temporal relations are cumulated down the syntactic trees through a mechanism of feature passing, which is typically syntactic (this obviously holds in general of Abusch's proposal, hence also of the discussed account of the simultaneous reading of (32)). It is not clear whether and how the syntactic theory can bear the burden of these two requirements. Invisible movement have recently come under the scrutiny of syntacticians who seem more wary than in the past about these matters. Concerning the feature-passing mechanism, it is not something that current theories of generative grammar seem so able, or even willing, to accommodate. So the basic problem of how temporal dependencies should be handled remains open.

On the semantic side, the de re account has a number of empirical and conceptual shortcomings. Given the constraint on the acquaintance relation, it can explain why an utterance of (36) is odd if Mary's symptoms do not persist at speech time. However, it has difficulties in explaining why the same utterance is odd if the symptoms persist but the situation has changed in relevant respects. Suppose, for instance, that Mary was indeed pregnant when John said what he did, that she delivered just a few days before the report, and that, as often happen in these cases, she still has a big belly. If this is the situation, the DAR report is odd, and the oddness seems to have to do more with the speaker's knowledge/beliefs – that is, with her propositional attitudes – than with John's. Interestingly, the converse also holds. If Mary was not pregnant at the saying time (John was wrong), is now pregnant, and has a big belly all the time (for whatever reasons), then again (36) is odd. As before, what matters is that if the speaker knows that the situation has changed, she isn't in a position to use a DAR sentence. These facts are not easily captured by the de re accounts just reviewed.

Finally, on the conceptual side, de re accounts of DAR sentences place a heavy epistemological burden on the speaker's shoulders: she must have quite detailed intuitions about the subject's original situation (mental state, one could say). On the other hand, it seems that one can use a DAR sentence without any information about what moved John into saying what he did (the big belly?). Short of saying that the speaker can postulate non-specific acquaintance relations, it is not clear how the vast majority of uses of DAR sentences can be accounted for. But non-specific acquaintance relations don't seem to be what Lewis had in mind when he introduced acquaintance relations; he seemed to mean that they should be of a very specific type.

A different approach to DAR sentences, trying to address those concerns, was proposed by Giorgi and Pianesi (2001b). They explicitly attempt to link the temporal interpretation with syntactic facts, while at the same time capitalizing on the idea that by using a DAR sentence the speaker expresses an attitude of hers. On the syntactic side, the basic observations concern the fact that in Italian, DAR contexts typically have the indicative mood, and reject complementizer deletion (see Giorgi and Pianesi 2000, 2001a):

(42)
Gianni ha detto *(che) tu eri arrabbiato.
Gianni has said (that) you were(IND) angry
‘Gianni said that you were angry.

(43)
Gianni credeva/temeva (che) tu fossi arrabbiato.
Gianni believed(IMPF)/feared(IMPF) that you were(SUBJ) angry
‘Gianni believed that you were angry.

(44)
Gianni ha detto che Maria è incinta.
Gianni has said that Maria is pregnant
‘Gianni said that Maria is pregnant.

(45)
*Gianni temeva che Maria sia/è incinta.
Gianni feared(IMPF) that Maria is(SUBJ)/is(IND) pregnant
‘Gianni feared that Maria is(SUBJ)/is(IND) pregnant.’

On the other hand, contexts that allow complementizer deletion, such as those induced by verbs like credere (believe) or temere (fear), do not allow the DAR. Thus, some connection seems to be at stake between CD and DAR. Giorgi and Pianesi's explanation is cast in a split-C framework: two distinct complementizers can be singled out in embedded clauses; namely, a lower one, called MOOD, which is related to the presence of an embedded subjunctive verb, and a higher one, C. MOOD is just the lexicalization of the mood features, which can also be realized syncretically (Giorgi and Pianesi 1997) in Infl. When the syncretic option is exerted, MOOD is absent, thence the appearance of complementizer deletion. On the other hand, C's features cannot be realized syncretically, hence C cannot be omitted. The relationship between the ban on CD and the possibility of the DAR, therefore, points to an important role to be played by C: the DAR obtains only if C is projected (irrespective of the specific tense chosen). To explain this relationship, Giorgi and Pianesi hypothesize that the complementizer C is endowed with temporal features (&tgr;-features) entering a relation with those of the embedded T, by either movement or matching. As a result, when the ILF for the embedded clause of (36) is computed and the interpretive contribution of tenses is spelled out, the same eventive variable is present in C and in T:

The C node is invariably associated with speaker orientation, so that the temporal features in C yield the ‘normal’ indexical value. Moreover, (37) is strengthened into a bi-conditional, to the effect that whenever a representation contains the temporal coordinate of an agent then it must express the content of an attitude by that agent.

Concerning (46a), three ILFs must be considered. The first is built from C's complement, XP in (46a); it is interpreted under a subject-oriented assignment, and reports the content of the subject's original dictum. The result is that the in-situ copy of the present tense provides for a pregnancy that overlaps with the subject's temporal coordinate. Then we have the node C itself, where the &tgr;-features are interpreted by means of the speaker-oriented assignment. The result is that the pregnancy state overlaps with the speaker's temporal coordinates as well. Finally, we have the ILF associated with the whole dominating CP, where the former two ILFs are put together in such a way that they are required to have coordinated value: whenever the one (the ILF for XP) is true, the other (that for C) is true as well, and vice versa. This coordination of truth-values is meant to account for the observation made above about the content of the speaker's attitude: the speaker maintains that if Mary was pregnant at the subject's time then the same pregnancy obtains at her time, and vice versa.

The following features of this approach should be noticed: it generalizes the idea, already discussed in section 3.2, that the content of attitude ascriptions, as expressed by ILFs, depends on the subject's coordinate (context/mental state) since it incorporates her temporal coordinates, and explicitly extends it to the speaker, by seeing C as the locus where speaker orientation comes to play a role. This approach shares with de re theories the idea that the tense is moved. However, it identifies the place where movement is directed to, namely, C, and motivates such a movement with the triggering &tgr;-features in C.

subsection.heading: 3.4 Temporal adverbials
subsection.p: If temporal entities (times) are part of the ontology underlying natural language, and reference to them proceeds the way it does with ordinary objects, we should be able to individuate the same range of referential phenomena observed with the latter. In particular, it should be possible to single out terms exhibiting direct reference to temporal entities, behaving as the counterparts of, say, a proper name such as John, or of a deictic/indexical term such as here or that man. It should also be possible to show that their semantic and syntactic properties are similar to those of ‘ordinary’ proper names or indexical/deictic terms.

Obvious candidates for direct reference in the temporal realm are the names of days and months used in isolation – e.g., Thursday, Sunday, and May. They can appear as expressions fixing the time of the event:

(47)
a. I met him (on) Thursday.
b. John will arrive in May.
They can also play the role of subjects/direct objects:

(48)
a. John spent Thursday at the seaside.
b. May was a beautiful month.

In all these cases, the reference of these expressions is indexical, crucially involving the use of the speaker's temporal coordinate. Thus, Thursday in (47a) or (48a) refers to the last such day before the utterance time; May in (47b) refers to the next such month after the utterance time, and in (48b) to the last one. In this sense, they constitute canonical examples of direct reference. Interestingly, they enter into syntactic configurations that have important similarities to that of proper names, as explored by Longobardi (1994). More precisely, Longobardi observed that in Italian, nominal arguments must be introduced by a category D:

(49)
a. La madre di Maria è partita.
the mother of Maria is left
‘The mother of Maria has left.’
b. *Madre di Maria è partita.
mother of Maria is left
‘Mother of Maria has left.’
c. È venuto Camaresi vecchio.
is come Camaresi old
Old Camaresi came. (Longobardi's ex. (29c))
d. *È venuto vecchio Camaresi.
is come old Camaresi
Old Camaresi came. (Longobardi's ex. (29b))
e. Bevo sempre vino.
drink-1sg always wine
‘I always drink wine.’ (Longobardi's ex. (12a))

This position can be occupied by an overt determiner (cf. (49a)), by the raised nominal head, as in (49c), or by an empty determiner, as in (49e), where a mass noun appears. Longobardi explains this pattern, and, in particular, the fact that proper nouns occupy the D0 position in syntax, by assuming that the functional category D has a feature [± ref] that must be checked by a corresponding feature on the noun. The feature ref is strong in Romance and weak in Germanic, and this explains the contrast between (49c) and (49d) on the one hand and (49a) and (49b) on the other:

(50)
a. Old John came.
b. *John old came.

Moreover, ref is connected to the referential properties of the whole DP. A proper name such as John has ref, because it refers directly to the relevant person. Given that ref is strong in Romance, Italian proper names must overtly rise to D0 from their base position (cf. (49c)), preventing adjectives from preceding proper nouns (cf. (49d)). On the other hand, the weak ref of Germanic allows English proper nouns to rise covertly, thus permitting the pronominal adjective of (50a). Finally, common nouns, such as madre (mother) in (49a) and (49b), are not object referring, and as such cannot be endowed with the ref feature. As a consequence, the overt article is needed.
Longobardi (1994) and Giorgi and Pianesi (1997) observe that names of days and names of months exhibit a similar behavior:

(51)
a. Ho passato (il) giovedì scorso al mare.
have-1sg spent (the) Thursday last at the seaside
‘I spent last Thursday at the seaside.’
b. Ho passato *(lo) scorso giovedì al mare.
have-1sg spent *(the) last Thursday at the seaside
‘I spent last Thursday at the seaside.’

(52)
a. (Il) Giovedì scorso è passato velocemente.
(the) Thursday last is passed quickly
‘Last Thursday passed quickly.’
b. *(Lo) scorso giovedì è passato velocemente.
(the) last Thursday is passed quickly
‘Last Thursday passed quickly.’

(53)
Ho passato giovedì al mare.
have-1sg spent Thursday at the seaside
‘I have spent Thursday at the seaside.’

(54)
a. Mario ha passato domenica sola al mare.
Mario has spent Sunday only-fem at the seaside
‘Mario spent only Sunday at the seaside.’
b. *Mario ha passato sola domenica al mare.
Mario has spent only-fem Sunday at the seaside
‘Mario spent only Sunday at the seaside.’

These examples reproduce the pattern in (49) and can be taken as evidence that the noun giovedì (Thursday) can overtly raise to D0, as proper names do in Longobardi's theory, and for similar reasons. Thus, in (49c) and (51a), with the postnominal adjective, the definite article may be dropped, showing that the noun has risen in the D0 position. When the adjective is prenominal, however, the article must be present, as in (49d) and (51b). Finally, (54a) and (54b) reproduce the same pattern with a non-temporal adjective, solo (only).
This behavior isn't reproduced with an adjective such as precedente (previous/before), as the contrast between (51–52) and (55) exemplifies:

(55)
a. Ho passato *(il) giovedì prima/precedente al mare.
have-1sg spent *(the) Thursday before at the seaside
‘I spent the Thursday before at the seaside.’
b. *(Il) Giovedì prima/precedente era passato velocemente.
(the) Thursday before had passed quickly
‘The Thursday before had passed quickly.’

Concerning proper nouns, Longobardi notes that the adjectives that tolerate the raising of the nominal head are those which can have a restrictive interpretation, in both prenominal and postnominal position:

(56)
a. ?Mario alto è venuto a trovarmi.
Mario tall is come to visit-me
‘Tall Mario came to visit me.’
b. Il Mario alto è venuto a trovarmi.
the Mario tall is come to visit-me
‘The tall Mario came to visit me.’

With a restrictive interpretation of the adjective alto (tall), (56a) is marginal, whereas an appositive reading is completely unavailable. The sentence improves with an article, as in (56b). If this reasoning is on the right track, one may extend it to the sentences in (55), observing that they contain restrictive phrases that are obligatorily postnominal.
Proper nouns yield better results with postnominal restrictive adjectives, such as bello (handsome), than with postnominal (restrictive) adverbials, such as prima (before):

(57)
Ci sono due Mari: uno bello e l’ altro brutto. ?Mario bello è venuto a trovarmi.
there are two Marios: one handsome and the other ugly. Mario handsome is come to visit-me
‘There are two Marios: one is handsome and the other is ugly. The handsome Mario came to visit me.’

(58)
C’ erano due Mari in fila: uno prima di me ed un altro dopo di me.
there were two Marios in row: one before me and another after me
‘There were two Marios in the queue: one was before me and the other after me.’
a. Il Mario prima di me è venuto a trovarmi.
the Mario before me is come to visit-me
‘The Mario before me came to visit me.’
b. *Mario prima di me è venuto a trovarmi.
Mario before me is come to visit-me
‘Mario before me came to visit me.’
The quasi-acceptability of (57) contrasts with the strong unacceptability of (58b).

This evidence seems to stress the role of modifiers in endowing the nominal head with object referring capabilities. E.g., adjectives such as scorso (last) in (51–52), being indexical, provide the nominal head with directly referential capabilities – that is, they provide [+ ref] – so that it can raise overtly to the D0 position in Italian. An adjective such as precedente (previous/before) does not have this possibility, so that the nominal head cannot raise to D0.

This discussion shows that direct reference (in the form of indexical reference) can be found in the temporal realm. Importantly, the expressions realizing it participate in the same syntactic pattern as those observed for objectual reference.
When the relevant expressions are used to temporally locate the event, the same pattern presented in (51–54) is reproduced:

(59)
a. Ho incontrato Mario (il) giovedì scorso.
have-1sg met Mario (the) Thursday last
‘I met Mario last Thursday.’
b. Ho incontrato Mario *(lo) scorso giovedì.
have-1sg met Mario the last Thursday
‘I met Mario last Thursday.’
c. Ho incontrato Mario giovedì.
have-1sg met Mario Thursday
‘I met Mario on Thursday.’

(60)
a. (Il) giovedì scorso ho telefonato a Mario.
(the) Thursday last have-1sg telephoned to Mario
‘The Thursday last I telephoned to Mario.’
b. *(Lo) scorso giovedì ho telefonato a Mario.
(the) last Thursday have-1sg telephoned to Mario
‘The last Thursday I telephoned Mario.’
c. Giovedì ho telefonato a Mario.
Thursday have-1sg telephoned to Mario
‘Thursday I telephoned to Mario.’

(61)
a. ?Mario è venuto a trovarmi domenica sola.
Mario is come to visit-me Sunday only-sg, fem
‘Mario came to visit me only on Sunday.’
b. *Mario è venuto a trovarmi sola domenica.
Mario is come to visit-me only-sg, fem Sunday.
‘Mario came to visit me only on Sunday.’

The article can be dropped in (59a) and (59c), where the adjective is in the prenominal position, showing that the nominal head has raised in (59a) and (59c). The article cannot be omitted in (59b), as the order adjective-noun shows, since the nominal head has not risen. Furthermore, these observations can be reproduced when the adverbial is in sentence-initial position (cf. (59a) and (59c)). Finally, (61) shows that, as in (54), the relevant behavior can be obtained not only with temporal adjectives such as scorso (last) but also with others, such as solo (only).

The data in (59) to (61) confirm the conclusion drawn above, and constitute evidence in favor of the hypothesis that temporal adverbs have argument status. In particular, (59b), (60b), and (61b) show that these phrases require a filled D0, a behavior which is typical of arguments. Hence, temporal expressions fixing the time of the event seem to be the lowest arguments in the VP shell (cf. Larson 1988b). To support this conclusion, note that the constraints seen above do not arise in non-argument position – that is, in predicative contexts:

(62)
a. Sono discorsi da scorsa domenica.
are-3pl talks from last Sunday
‘These talks are typical of last Sunday.’
b. Sono discorsi da domenica scorsa.
are-3pl talks from Sunday last
‘These talks are typical of last Sunday.’
c. Ho dichiarato questo giorno (la) sola domenica dell’anno in cui si possa mangiare carne.
have-1sg declared this day (the) only Sunday of the year in which can eat-3sg meat
‘I have declared this day as the only Sunday of the year in which it is possible to eat meat.’

In argument position, the lack of the determiner is due to the overt raising of the nominal head to D0. Therefore, adjectives such as scorso (last) and solo (only) cannot appear in prenominal position (cf. (59b) and (61b)). On the other hand, predicative positions do not require DPs, and bare NPs are allowed. Hence, prenominal adjectives are possible without a determiner:

(63)
Mario si è mascherato da vecchio spartano.
Mario himself is dressed-up as old Spartan
‘Mario dressed himself up as an old Spartan.’
Temporal adverbials manifest the same pattern in predicative contexts:

(64)
Il giorno dell’ esame era (il) venerdì prima.
the day before the examination was (the) Friday before
‘The day before the examination was (the) Friday before.’
Example (64), where venerdì prima ‘Friday before’ is an NP, contrasts with (55).

In conclusion, it can be shown in a non-trivial way not only that direct reference is available in the temporal realm, as expected if temporal reference is available to natural language, but also that the syntax of direct reference for temporal phrases is, in relevant respects, similar to that of direct reference to ordinary objects. Finally, these conclusions hold both for temporal expressions in subject and object positions, and for those fixing the time of the event, showing that the latter deserve to be treated as arguments rather than as modifiers.

subsection.heading: 4 A non-referential approach
subsection.p: After this cursory review of the merits of the referential approach – namely, the idea that the interpretive properties of tenses and temporal expression are best explained by having variables in the object language that refer to temporal entities – it might seem strange to consider theories claiming that temporal entities and temporal reference should be banned from the basic ontology and from semantics. Yet this has been an influential view, especially in philosophy, and it has recently found more than episodic links with linguistics, thanks to Ludlow (1999). The importance of this enterprise to linguistics is that it tries to show that the very basic question of whether reference to time is to be admitted or not among the tools of the theory is still an open issue, and that it must be solved both by taking seriously metaphysical concerns, and by comparing alternative theories on an empirical basis.

In this section we will present the basic tenets of Ludlow's theory, trying first to provide reasons for the move, and to discuss the theory's machinery and some of its applications to selected phenomena, often the same as those addressed in our review of referential approaches. Given that Ludlow is our sole source, we will try to be as faithful as possible to his exposition. Occasionally, however, we will integrate the analyses, paying attention to keeping to Ludlow's original intuitions.

subsection.heading: 4.1 A-series vs. B-series
subsection.p: Metaphysical concerns are crucial for anyone thinking that the goal of semantic theory is to investigate the ‘tacit’ knowledge that permits people to draw appropriate language–world connections. Such a theory is, for instance, an absolute truth theory of semantic knowledge of the kind we have been often resorting to in this chapter – namely, an axiomatic theory comprising axioms giving the referents of terminal symbols, and rules for producing the semantic value of non-terminal nodes starting from the former values. For the theory to make interesting claims, it must rely on some understanding of what is out there in the world, hence it cannot escape some amount of metaphysical commitment. By the same token, Ludlow argues that linguistic inquiry can in turn contribute to further investigation on metaphysical issues.

As far as time is concerned, two metaphysical positions have stimulated the ingenuity of scholars. According to the first (Russell, Reichenbach, Einstein, etc.), time is a sequence of unchanging tenseless events, whereby “future events, past events, and present events are all equally real” (Ludlow 1999: 1). This view is known as the B-series theory of time (McTaggart 1908), or the untensed conception (Mellor 1981), and is the one underlying referential approaches to time in language. It is opposed by the A-series or tensed doctrine, which retorts that “it is fundamental to the notion of time that events, or perhaps propositions, have genuine temporal status” (Ludlow 1999: 2). As a consequence, the metaphysical status of past and future events might be different, corresponding to different properties.

The B-series conception maintains that the basic relations are the familiar ones which can be construed from the notion of precedence, and allow us to talk about an event/time as being earlier-than, later-than, or simultaneous-with, another event/time. These notions suffice to analyze and explain away change, which is taken not to be metaphysically real, but to have only a psychological status. In other words, change is apparent: events/times are given, and all we can say is that some of them precede and/or are simultaneous with some others. We do have the ‘feeling’ of change, but, as observed, this is not metaphysically real and has no direct counterpart in the underlying ontology; in this sense, the B-series is objective.

The alternative account replies that change is metaphysically real: a past event is ontologically different from a future event, and this requires that the relation of precedence be abandoned in favor of the basic notions of past, present, and future (thus avoiding constructing the latter from the former). The consequence is that time entities with their usual ordering are not part of the underlying ontology, and the whole repertory of referential semantics, with its resources (direct reference, quantification, the traditional views about indexicality) cannot be used to account for temporal talk. For the same reasons, the A-series view is not friendly to traditional tense logics. As observed in section 3, though the latter eschew explicit talk about temporal entities from the object language, they have it in the metalanguage. The A-series conception opposes this move too; there are no time points (or intervals) in the ontology, so they cannot be manipulated at any level of the logical language.

The two opposing fields have both metaphysical and semantic facts to duel about. We won't insist on the former, for which we refer the reader to Ludlow (1999) and to Bonomi (2002). Concerning the latter, a case in point is constituted by temporal indexicals. Ludlow considers the situation of a person (himself, apparently) who thinks:
(65) My fifth anniversary is March 12.
Upon discovering that the very day of that thought is March 12, he shouts:
(66) My fifth anniversary is today!

These two tokens exemplify one of the classic problems of indexicals. If we take a referential view of times, and hypothesize that the meaning of an utterance is a tenseless (impersonal) proposition, then the two utterances above may end up having the same meaning – namely, the proposition that Ludlow's anniversary is March 12. But clearly, there's a difference between the kind of knowledge communicated by (65) and that pertaining to (66). Even if we admit that the two utterances have the same content/meaning – e.g., that a particular event (Ludlow's anniversary) occurs at a particular time – we need to account for the cognitive difference. The latter seems to consist of the fact that by uttering (66), the speaker acknowledges that March 12 (the day of his anniversary) is the same day as that of his utterance. The particular mood he is in is caused by this very fact, not by the (much less urgent) piece of information that his anniversary occurs at such-and-such a time. A possible move suggested in the literature (Perry 1969, 1977; Kaplan 1990; etc.) consists in capturing the difference by means of the notion of the character/role of an (indexical) expression. Characters are entities which connect meanings to contexts of speech/thoughts in such a way that, given a context, the character of an indexical expression provides its meaning. In the case at hand, March 12 and today are indexical expressions (the former is taken to refer to the next such day), and have different characters. The meanings (the time individuals) they provide are what enter the truth-conditions of the two utterances. Larson and Segal (1995) suggest executing this in the following way:

(67)
a. Val(x, March 12, σ) iff σ(March 12) = x
b. Val(x, today, σ) iff σ(today) = u = x
These axioms yield the following truth-conditions:

(68)
a. If u is an utterance of ‘My fifth anniversary is March 12’, s is the utterer of u, and t is the time of u, then u is true iff s's anniversary is at March 12.
b. If u is an utterance of ‘My fifth anniversary is today’, s is the utterer of u, and t is the time of u, then u is true iff s's anniversary is at t.

It should be noted that, in a sense, characters remain outside semantics; actually, they play a role in determining truth-conditions, but they do so only by delivering meanings, used to compute truth-conditions. This state of affairs has the consequence that even the differences between (65) and (66) remain beyond the reach of semantics. Indeed, the time of utterance happens to be March 12 for both sentences, hence the truth-conditions in (68) end up being the same. So, while the notion of character has some role in accounting for the different status of (65) as compared to (66), this remains outside the semantic realm.

For those who are dissatisfied with this outcome, believing that the difference between (65) and (66) should be reflected in the semantics/truth-conditions, the possibility is open of resorting to token-reflexive truth-conditions à la Reichenbach (1947), which incorporate the reference to the very utterance (thought) token in the truth-conditions. In this case, the truth-conditions for (65) and (66) are as follows:

(69)
a. If u is an utterance of ‘My fifth anniversary is March 12’, s is the utterer of u, and t is the time of u, then this utterance is true iff s's anniversary is at t.
b. If u is an utterance of ‘My fifth anniversary is today’, s is the utterer of u, and t is the time of u, then this utterance is true iff s's anniversary is at t-the day of this very utterance.

Now, the right-hand sides of the truth-conditions differ, for the second explicitly mentions the utterance token when spelling out the referent of the indexical, whereas the other doesn't. So it seems that we have both captured the different cognitive significance of our two utterances, and managed to keep the distinction within semantics.

Successful as it may appear, however, the token-reflexive strategy has its own problems. In the first place, it is not clear how the required reference to the utterance can be introduced in the semantic machinery, a seemingly technical problem that we won't discuss here. Second, a case can be construed that causes the collapse (in Ludlow's view) of the token-reflexive strategy. The point to be made draws on observations made by Castañeda (1967) about token-reflexivity applied to the first person. In the case of temporality, it turns on the truth-conditions of utterances of (70a), which are as in (70b) according to the token-reflexive strategy:

(70)
a. There is no (spoken) language.
b. If u is an utterance of ‘There is no spoken language’, s is the utterer of u, and t is the time of u, then this utterance is true iff there is no spoken language at t-the time of this very utterance.

The problem is that though utterances of (70a) are false, they are contingently so (it might have been the case that nobody uttered anything); (70b), however, is necessarily false, because of the presence of the reference to the utterance token in the truth-conditions. If we drop such a reference, however, we give up the prospect of bringing context/character within the semantics. Ludlow's conclusion is that the tension between a satisfactory account of temporal indexicality and the analysis of sentences that are about linguistic tokens, such as (70a), originates from the very resources of the B-series – namely, times and reference thereto. So attempts at getting rid of the B-series seem justified.

Are there any reasons, on the other hand, to prefer the B-series to the A-series? Of course there are, and we have already presented some of them when we discussed the shortcomings of temporal logics: complex tenses and anaphora are the best-known and most discussed problems, not only for temporal logics, but for any genuine A-series accounts. Given that the latter do not even admit temporal entities in the ontology, how can temporal anaphora be dealt with? And how can complex tenses be accounted for?

The only effective reply is to try and develop an explicit A-theory semantics. In this respect, we saw that the tensed approach takes change as real and as having a privileged status. How can such a primacy be captured? What does it mean that all we need are the notions of past, present, and future? Moreover, change must be accounted for in a non-circular way; it wouldn't help to resort to the metaphor of passing/flowing time, because such a passage or flow already takes place in time. The only solution seems to be that being past, present, or future be seen as properties that propositions (or proposition-like objects) have or fail to have, and that change is simply the fact that a certain proposition was future, is present, and will be past. This, according to Ludlow, was Prior's (1967) position, often confused with the idea that there was a time at which a certain proposition was future, there is a time at which it is present, and there will be a time at which it will be past. The latter is what lies behind the attempts at capturing Prior's intuitions in tense logics, but those statements obviously fail to do justice to the untensed view of the A-series, for they admit temporal entities, and admit reference to them, even if only at the metalanguage level. Taking Prior's idea seriously amounts, therefore, to requiring that Past be “an indexical predicate that holds of a proposition-like object, effectively displaying the indexical sense of a past-tense morpheme” (Ludlow 1999: 97).
Consider the following axioms:

(71)
a. Val(true, [XP T YP], σ) iff for some x Val(x, T, σ) and x = σ[]YP[].
b. Val(x, Tpast, σ) iff x was true.
c. Val(x, Tpres, σ) iff x is true.
d. Val(x, Tfut, σ) iff x will be true.

The first axiom assigns the value true to the clausal structure [XP T YP] iff the ILF of YP (a proposition-like object) is the value associated with the tense node. As with tense logical approaches, this treatment relies on the idea that there is an appropriate representation in which the tense morpheme takes clausal scope. The contribution of the tense morpheme, in turn, is ruled by (71b–d), which implement the idea that tenses behave as indexical predicates of proposition-like objects. Once, e.g., (71a) and (71b) are put together, we can derive the following theorem for an utterance of John left:
(72) Val(true, [XP Tpast [IP John leave]], σ) iff σ[]IP[] was true.

That is, that utterance is true iff the ILF of the IP phrase was true. To take another (well-known) example, consider utterances of the sentence My root canal is over used to express relief after a dreadful session at the dentist (similar examples are discussed by Prior 1967, Higginbotham 1995, and others). The present theory assigns it the truth-conditions in (73a), whereas the Larson-and-Segal-style B-series theory would yield (73b):

(73)
a. Val(true, [XP Tpast [∃e(e is the event of my root canal)]], σ) iff σ[][∃e(e is the event of my root canal)][] was true.
b. If u is an utterance at t, by s of [XP Tpast [∃e(e is the event of my root canal)]], then Val(true, u, σ) iff ∃e(e is the event of my root canal and e<t).

As argued by many, (73b) does not explain why one can express relief by uttering that sentence: what is there to be relieved about in the fact that an event precedes a certain time (or another event)? Arguably, (73a) fares better: the sense of relief stems from the fact that a given proposition (the ILF in (73a)) is past for the speaker.
Following the same path, it is possible to define axioms for other indexicals, such as yesterday or tomorrow, by treating them in the same disquotational manner as past, present, and future in (71):

(74)
a. Val(true, [XP Adv YP], σ) iff there is an x such that Val(x, ADV, σ) and x = σ[]YP[].
b. Val(x, yesterday/tomorrow, σ) iff x was true yesterday/will be true tomorrow.

subsection.heading: 4.2 Complex tenses
subsection.p: An important development of the theory concerns complex tenses. The account has similarities with the revised Reichenbachian analysis of Giorgi and Pianesi (1997) and others discussed in section 3.1, since it takes complex tenses to involve multi-clausal constructions. Giorgi and Pianesi exploit two tense categories (T1, which is responsible for the relationship between the event time and the reference time, and T2, which attends to the relationship between the reference time and speech time), and hypothesize that the clause hosting T2 is a complement of that where T1 lies, both being always explicit. Ludlow, on the other hand, provides LF representations for complex tenses based on matrix-adjunct structures, where the adjunct is a when-, before-, or after-clause that might remain implicit. Again, the axioms for the connectives rely on a disquotational treatment:

(75)
a. Val(true, [S S1 when S2], σ) iff Val(true, S1, σ) when Val(true, S2, σ).
b. Val(true, [S S1 before S2], σ) iff Val(true, S1, σ) before Val(true, S2, σ).
c. Val(true, [S S1 after S2], σ) iff Val(true, S1, σ) after Val(true, S2, σ).

After this, it is hypothesized that all natural languages have (implicit) when-clauses, whose structure is the same as that of explicit ones, and whose tense is in concord with that of the main clause.
