With this in place, the syntactic structure for a pluperfect such as (75a) is as in (75b), where the past tense prefixed to the before-clause results from the requirement that the tenses of the main and adjunct clauses match:

(76)
a. had left
b. Tpast[S] before Tpast[ . . . ]

Attempting a Reichenbachian analogy, the matrix clause of (76b) expresses the relationship between the event time and the speech time; the adjunct relates the reference time to the speech time, and the connectives when, before, and after take care of linking the event and the reference times. This differs in important respects from the neo-Reichenbachian analyses: the latter, in fact, link the reference time both to the event time and to the speech time, sometimes encoding such a dependency, as in Giorgi and Pianesi (1997) in the morphosyntax of tenses.
The schematic LF in (76b) and the axioms given above yield the truth-conditions in (77b) for the sentence in (77a):

(77)
a. John had left.
b. Val(true, ‘John had left’, σ) iff σ[]∃e(leaving(e) ∧ Agent(e, John))[] was true before σ[][ . . . ][] was true.

To repeat, tenses introduce indexical predicates that are treated disquotationally: what a past tense contributes is that the ILF corresponding to the de-tensed clause was true. There is no mention of times, as we would have in temporal logics (the proposition was true at a past time = the (de-tensed) proposition is true at a past time). Complex tenses require implicit when-, before-, or after-clauses, with temporal connectives also treated disquotationally.

Ludlow argues that thanks to this machinery, the theory avoids one of the commonest charges against temporal logics – namely, the unconstrained nature of the account of complex tenses (see section 2). Contrary to the case of temporal logics, the problem does not arise here, since complex tenses correspond not to the nesting operators, but to implicit clauses introduced by appropriate temporal connectives. Operator composition is not required, hence unwanted combinations are expected not to arise. As Ludlow (1999: 124) puts it: “The system merely recapitulates the structure made available by the system of explicit temporal conjunctions, and inherits the constraints on that system.”
At this juncture, one might object that the possibility of predicting non-existing tenses might not be completely ruled out, since temporal clauses can be nested:
(78) John left when you started to address Mary after she provoked Henry.

To the extent that the syntax of implicit when-clauses parallels that of explicit ones, nesting temporal clauses cannot be dismissed; hence the danger of overgenerating complex tenses isn't completely avoided.

As observed, the implicit temporal clauses can play the role of the Reichenbachian reference time. The latter, in turn, is a device for picking up contextually relevant times. Thus, for an utterance of John had (already) left to be felicitous, a contextually relevant time seems necessary, which plays the role of the reference time, as in the following discourse:
(79) Mary entered. John had (already) left.
This is a case of temporal anaphora, and in general the reference time has anaphoric properties.

As we know, A-series theories ban temporal reference: there are no singular propositions about times, but only general ones, in the sense that none depends upon a particular temporal entity. So Ludlow accounts for the anaphoric properties of Reichenbach's reference time by deploying an E-type theory of temporal anaphora. Accordingly, (possibly implicit) temporal anaphors stand proxy for when-clauses, which provide the required descriptive content (for the notion of E-type anaphora, see Evans 1977). Thus, in the discourse above, the second sentence would have the LF:
(80) [[Tpast [John leave]] before TPast [ . . . ]]
The content provided by the before-clause, in the case at hand, is something like Mary entered. Hence, the resulting truth-conditions are:
(81) Val(true, [[Tpast [John leave]] before Tpast[ . . . ]], σ) iff Val(true, [Tpast [John leave]], σ) before Val(true, Tpast[ . . . ], σ).

Eventually, the second sentence of our small discourse is uttered truthfully iff it was true that John left and this was before it was true that Mary entered. Such a strategy, it is suggested, can be generalized to all cases of temporal anaphora. If workable, it would prove that A-series approaches can handle temporal anaphora, thus replying to an important objection made by its opponents.

subsection.heading: 4.3 Temporal adverbs
subsection.p: We saw that locating adverbs like July 13, 1999 seem to provide a clear example of (rigid) reference to temporal entities. In the theory presently under discussion, they can be analyzed as being (elements of) implicit when-clauses:

(82)
a. John left (on) July 13, 1999.
b. [Tpast [John leave] when Tpast [ . . . July 13, 1999 . . . ]]

The content of the (partially) implicit when-clause can be taken to be the result of some process of temporal measurement – e.g., ‘when the calendar said July 13, 1999’. Notice the (implicit) tense prefixed to the adjunct clause in (82b). This follows from Ludlow's hypothesis that implicit when-clauses behave syntactically as explicit ones, so that their tenses are somehow coordinated with that of the main clause. In our case, the tense of the matrix is past, so that the adjunct clause has the same tense. In a different context it could be a future or present tense:

(83)
a. John will leave (on) July 13, 2005.
b. [Tfut [John leave] when Tfut [ . . . July 13, 2005 . . . ]]
In this case, the truth-conditions are that ‘John will leave when the calendar says July 13, 2005.’

This treatment can be extended to temporal expressions that exhibit contextual variability, such as July 13, or Thursday. In many cases they behave as indexicals, requiring additional information of linguistic provenance to define their interpretive contribution. Thus, according to whether the main tense is past or future, Thursday may mean either the last such day before the utterance, or the next one. In other words, they do not seem to be intrinsically tensed, but import the relevant information from other phrases. Hence, they are different from, and not amenable to the same treatment as, yesterday and tomorrow. In the present framework, one could attempt the following strategy. Let us consider next Thursday, and hypothesize that next is an indexical predicate true of proposition-like objects:
(84) Val(x, next, σ) iff x next true.

The axiom for next is similar to that of a tense, treating it disquotationally. We can pursue the parallelism further, and suggest that, within an implicit when-clause, next can play the role of a tense; more precisely, of a future tense. Thence, it will be available when the matrix tense is a future, and it will be ruled out in the presence of a past tense. From what we already know, we can now derive:
(85) Val(true, [ . . . next Thursday], σ) iff σ[][ . . . Thursday . . . ][] next true.
That is, next Thursday is true iff the clock says Thursday will (next) be true. For a sentence such as John will leave next Thursday we have:
(86) Val(true, [John will leave next Thursday], σ) iff Val(true, [John will leave], σ) when Val(true, [next Thursday], σ).
With this, utterances of John will leave next Thursday are true iff John leave will be true when next Thursday will be true, i.e., when the clock says Thursday will (next) be true.

The case of bare temporal expressions, as in John will leave (on) Thursday, now follows. We need only recall that the tense (or the category playing the role of tense in the relevant phrase) must agree with that of the matrix. Because of this, the future-like next will be selected, giving:
(87) Val(true, [John will leave Thursday], σ) iff Val(true, [John will leave], σ) when Val (true, [next Thursday], σ).
We have written ‘next’ in italics to indicate that in this case it is not explicit, but stems from the general requirement ruling tense compatibility between matrix clauses and when-clauses.

As can be seen, the sketched analyses do not exploit times: there is no resort to entities such as the day July 13 or the hour five o’clock. What you have are measure systems that provide tags related to particular events: striking five vs. saying July 13. And the very event of measuring, of course, is tensed; thus, it occurred, occurs, or will occur.

Admittedly, the discussion is very cursory, but it reflects the status of the theory as developed by Ludlow (1999). It should also be observed that it is not clear how explicit talk about time entities and about what in a B-series approach appear as ordinal/metrical/topological properties can be accounted for. Thus, what should be done with the third Thursday, or with in two hours, for two months, etc? (This also relates to a conceptual problem we overlooked with the proposed treatment for next, for the idea of something being ‘next true’ seems to incorporate an ordinal notion of truth.)
Another important issue involves adverbs (and other devices) that have been argued by B-series theorists to be quantified over times/events:

(88)
a. I always meet Mary.
b. ∀t (∃e′ (meet(e′) ∧ Agent(e′, I) ∧ Theme(e′, Mary) ∧ at(e′, e)).

(89)
a. I often meet Mary.
b. Many t(∃e(meet(e) ∧ Agent(e′, I) ∧ Theme(e′, Mary) ∧ at(t, e)).

The strategy suggested by Ludlow involves substitutional (rather than objectual) quantification over when-clauses. More precisely, times are reintroduced as second-order entities built out of when-clauses, in such a way that for a given sentence S and a given context of utterance c, a ‘derived’ time, is the set of clauses S′ that are true when S is true. For instance, if S is ‘John sang’ and we know that at that time Mary danced, his brother slept, etc., then the contextually determined ‘time’ of S is t={‘Mary danced’, ‘his brother slept’, . . . }. With this, the truth-conditions for (88a) and (89a) are:

(90)
a. For every time t, there is an S in t such that ‘I meet Mary when “S” ’ is true.
b. For many a time t, there is an S in t such that ‘I meet Mary when “S” ’ is true.

This seems to solve the problem of temporal quantification in an A-series framework: what you quantify over in sentences such as (89a) are not times/events, but descriptions of events. These are context-dependent, as they should be, and as they are acknowledged by any objectual quantification account (in that case, the issue is how to restrict quantifications to contextually relevant times/events/situations).
One possible problem concerns the extension of this strategy to sentences such as (91):
(91) When I got to London I always met Mary.
Are they to be accounted for along the lines of (92)?
(92) For every S=[I got to London], ‘I met Mary when “S” ’ is true.

If so, the role of quantification actually is in danger of being emptied. For there is only one sentence – namely, I got to London – in question, so that you evaluate the right-hand side of (92) only once, obtaining the sentence I met Mary when I got to London. This, in turn, is true iff it was true that I met Mary when it was true that I got to London. Eventually, we have semel-factive truth-conditions. The speaker of (91), however, intends the when-clause to describe many events of going to London, but then it seems that we cannot use the same sentence for picking them up. In the end, if (92) is not the right way to address sentences such as (91), what should we do with it?

Beside this observation, some questions come naturally to mind. For instance, could one try to mimic the B-series on a contextual basis (e.g., by reintroducing a later-than relation on derived times, building on the connective before), thus recovering part of its expressiveness, and address, e.g., the problems we saw above with temporal locating phrases? and if derived time entities are needed because of quantification and/or because we can talk about their ordinal/metrical/topological properties, then doesn't this implicitly speak in favor of B-series approaches?

subsection.heading: 4.4 Sequence of tense
subsection.p: Let us briefly turn to sequence of tense in an A-series framework:

(93)
a. John said that Mary was ill.
b. [John said that [Mary was ill when [ . . . ]]]

The implicit when-clause could be taken to E-type-refer to the time of the matrix event – that is, it could be something like [when [John did the saying]] – or, as Ludlow suggests, it can be an E-type anaphora to some other contextually relevant clause, e.g., ‘when John went home’. The first option could then be used to account for the simultaneous reading of (90), whereas the latter might provide for the shifted reading. Such a suggestion incorporates the independent view of tenses (Dowty 1982b; Abusch 1997), according to which tenses in matrix clauses behave the same way as in matrices. However, it is inadequate, for the reasons discussed in section 3.2: not all past sentences will do, but only those that are not future with respect to the subject (John). So, to adopt a referential jargon, (93a) cannot be a true report of a speech of John's where he says ‘Mary will be ill in two days.’

When dealing with B-series theories, it was argued that these and other cases point to the necessity of representing the subject's (= the attitude's agent) coordinate in the ILF of the subordinate clause. In essence, it was said that temporal indexicality, at least as far as tenses are concerned, must be relativized to subjects. The proposal was implemented by distinguishing assignment sequences for the speaker from those for the subject, and have the latter used for the ILF of the complement clause of propositional attitude predicates.

In the present framework, and with the present implementation of the A-series view, one might wonder whether this process of relativizing indexicals to subjects’ contexts is still available. Tenses, in fact, are treated disquotationally, and their indexicality is not articulated anywhere, but directly used. Thus, in the axiom below, it is the metalanguage was on the right-hand side that bears the burden of indexicality, being naturally interpreted as the user's (speaker's):
(94) Val(x, Past, σ) iff x was true.

On the other hand, in the cases we are interested in – say, the shifted reading of (93a) – we would like to say that both the was of the embedded clause and the tense of the implicit when-clause (or, if you prefer, the relevant perspective) are John's (the subject's). In the case of the simultaneous reading (and pending an explanation of SOT), the embedded tense expresses a present tense from John's perspective, etc. Given that, as observed, the indexicality of tenses is not articulated anywhere, it seems that the only possibility of the A-series approach capturing those intuitions consists in changing the way evaluation is accomplished. For instance, we could propose that the LFs of the embedded clauses of attitude reports are (or can be) evaluated by using a simulation strategy. In order to compute the correct ILF (or whatever it is that represents the content of the reported attitude), people project themselves onto, and adopt, the subject's egocentric perspective. Thus, when interpreting an utterance of (93a), the speaker/hearer continues to use axiom (94), however she does so, as if she were the subject, thus turning the tense into that of the (simulated) subject. This line of thought can be extended to DAR sentences (see section 3.3). If we agree that movement of the embedded tense to the higher C creates two copies of the temporal features, then we can retain the idea that the first, in-situ copy is evaluated in a simulative mode (as if it were the subject's), and that the other copy is evaluated in the ordinary mode (as being the speaker's). (Perhaps Ludlow could subscribe to the simulation strategy applied to tenses in subordinate context. He explicitly mentions it as a possibility for indexicals in general, 1999: 64.)

subsection.heading: 4.5 Taking stock of the A-series approach
subsection.p: Our survey of the A-series, tensed theory has been very cursory, both for reasons of space, and because the reference work (Ludlow 1999) is itself often cursory. Both in Ludlow's case and in ours, the goal was to show that the approach deserves to be pursued, that it can be motivated on both linguistic and non-linguistic grounds, and that, in the end, it can be compared to competing approaches by resorting to the usual notions and tools of descriptive and explanatory adequacy. Some critical observations, beyond those already provided during the discussion, can be made, though.

An important point concerns the burden Ludlow's program places on syntax. This is a heavy one and requires more investigation before the empirical and theoretical consequences of the theory can be properly assessed. For instance, the extensive use of implicit when-/before-/after-clauses requires that their status be better investigated and clarified. As it turns out from our survey, these clauses can be completely implicit, as in the case of complex tenses, or part of their content may be visible, as with locating temporal adverbial. As to partially explicit when-clauses, one could think about adapting and extending the analysis Den Dikken et al. (1996) have proposed for intensional verbs such as seek, which they suggest also take (partially) implicit complement clauses. Borrowing ideas developed in that work, one might hypothesize that partially implicit when-clauses for temporal adverbials have a null verb with an underspecified semantic, so that the resulting structure would be (95), with the subject also being implicit:
(95) [Subj [VP V [three o’clock]]]
One could then go on by suggesting that Subj be spelled out as some measure system (the calendar, the clock, etc.), and that the implicit verb be given the following lexical axiom:
(96) Val(<x, y, e>, VERB, σ) iff e is an event of time measurement, x is the measuring tool/system, and y is the measure.

Again, this is just a possible way to proceed, and more work is needed to establish this on firmer grounds. Also, the status of temporal phrases as PPs or DPs should be considered. Perhaps expressions consisting of DPs could be integrated into the present view along the lines suggested above, as arguments of implicit verbs of implicit clauses. The move is not so straightforward for PPs, for the same (implicit) verb should select either them or DPs.
More serious difficulties are raised by temporal phrases in subject or direct object position:

(97)
a. I spent Thursday/the last month/the period between May and July at the seaside.
b. May was a beautiful month.
Should those expressions be treated as part of implicit when-clauses, availing oneself of paraphrases such as (98a) for (97a) and (98b) for (97b)?

(98)
a. I was at the seaside when [ . . . Thursday . . . ].
b. It was a beautiful month when [ . . . May . . . ].

Though perhaps workable for (97a), the strategy seems more difficult with (97b). For what would beautiful be predicated of? Should we resort to months, hence times, as second-order/derived entities? And given that the latter are sets of propositions, does it make any sense to say that beautiful is predicated of (sets of) them? The problem is even more acute in light of an example discussed by Bonomi (2002):
(99) Last Monday will be described by the newspapers as ‘Black Monday’.

It seems impossible, here, to resort to the when-clause strategy, for what paraphrase based on it could do the work? And, even if this were possible, attention should be paid to ensuring that whatever at LF corresponds to last Monday be not in the scope of the future tense – a problem which, as might be noted, is reminiscent of similar difficulties temporal logic approaches had in dealing with the scope interactions between the tense operator and those of noun phrases (see section 2).

In the end, even if the when-clause strategy can be made to work properly for locating temporal phrases, it is hard to see what the treatment of the same expressions could be like when they appear as subjects or objects. From the point of view of linguistic theory, referential approaches have an obvious advantage over non-referential ones here: whereas the former can treat temporal phrases uniformly, irrespective of whether they serve to locate the event or function as subjects/objects, the tensed approach might end up needing to maintain an asymmetry between the two.

Turning to fully implicit clauses, they are crucial for E-type temporal anaphora. The choice here is between truly implicit (non-visible, but syntactically active) clauses, or null pronouns that, in virtue of the E-type analysis, yield clausal-like contributions to the truth-conditions. Ludlow explicitly considers the first alternative, speaking of LF representations at which implicit clauses are available. An important point, in this respect, is how those LF representations are built from available material in the case of complex tenses:

(100)
a. Pluperfect: had left Tpast[S] before Tpast[ . . . ].
b. Future perfect: will have left Tfut[S] before Tfut [ . . . ].
c. Future: in future Tfut[S] after Tfut[ . . . ].

According to the examples given, the main clauses contain the verb, and are prefixed by a tense that seems to be the one originally appearing on the auxiliary. So in John had left, the verb appears in the main clause, and the latter is prefixed by the past tense of the auxiliary: [S Past [S John aux leave] . . . ]. This configuration can be obtained by letting the tense (covertly) take wide scope, and the auxiliary be interpretively inert. The participle marking on the verb, in turn, seems to play a role in determining the type of connective to be used: before in the case of the pluperfect tense and of the future perfect tense. Maybe this is due to some kind of agreement between some feature of the main verb (a tense feature, an aspectual one?) and the connective.

That this reconstruction of how LFs for complex tenses are derived is on the right track seems to be confirmed by the explicit attempt Ludlow makes (1999: 126) at analyzing connectives such as before and after as the combination of a past or future tense morpheme and the connective when. The tense morpheme thus introduced takes narrow scope, so that the LFs in (100) can be replaced by the following ones:

(101)
a. Pluperfect: had left Tpast [Tpast [S] when [ . . . ]].
b. Future perfect: will have left Tfut [Tpast [S] when [ . . . ]].
c. Future: in future Tfut[Tfut [S] when [ . . . ]].

With this, the truth-conditions for John left become it was true that (it was true that John leave) when . . . , with the dots indicating the implicit when-clause. Note that (101) provides for a more straightforward derivation from the surface string than (100), and one which is more in line with current hypotheses about the syntax of tenses – e.g., Giorgi and Pianesi (1997): the tense on the auxiliary (T1) takes wide scope over the whole sentence, whereas that contributed by the past participle (T2) takes scope only over the main clause. Hence, it seems advisable to drop (100) and directly consider (101) as candidate for the LF representation of complex tenses.

The second strategy suggested for complex tenses has the advantage of providing an acceptable treatment of the present perfect tense. This is missing from Ludlow's inventory; if we try to fill this gap by applying the first procedure sketched above, we obtain for John has left the following LF, which is clearly wrong (contradictory, it seems):
(102) Tpres [S John leave] before Tpres [ . . . ].
If the second strategy is used (the one exploiting when-clauses with T2 taking narrow scope over the main clause), then we have:
(103) Tpres [Tpast [John leave] when [ . . . ]].

This representation does not yield contradiction, and has truth-conditions to the effect that John has left is true iff it is true that (it was true that John leave) when . . . , where the dots, as usual, stand for the implicit when-clause. Given that the tense having scope over the latter is the outermost present, we can conclude that John has left is true iff it was true that John leave when I speak.

This reconstruction of the present perfect is quite faithful to Reichenbach's (1947) intuition, which distinguished the present perfect from the simple past because with the former the reference time is/overlaps with the speech time, whereas in the latter the reference time is/overlaps with the event time. In the current A-series theory, the simple past features a when-clause in the scope of a past tense:
(104) Tpast[S . . . ] when Tpast [S . . . ]

whereas the present perfect has a present tense when-clause (cf. (103)). The presence of the latter is crucial for the A-series account of the present perfect, much as the idea that the reference time is/overlaps with the speech time was for Reichenbach: without it, (103) would reduce to the simple fact that it was true that John leave, thus becoming very similar to (104). It should also be recalled that the first attempts at capturing the semantics of the present perfect within a tense logical approach failed because it was analyzed as the combination Pres Past[S . . . ], which reduces to Past[S . . . ], this being the same representation postulated for the simple past. What those theories lacked was the acknowledgment (and means) of the role of contextual factors in tense interpretation, something stressed by Reichenbach and his followers through the use of reference time. Ludlow's tensed theory avoids this problem thanks to the device of when-clauses and E-type anaphora.

subsection.heading: 5 Conclusion
subsection.p: To conclude, it seems that the non-referential, tensed approach (as worked out by Ludlow) fares well with tenses (in both main and subordinate clauses), and that their treatment as indexical predicates and the disquotational semantics given can be very promising both theoretically and empirically.

On the other hand, the theory, as it stands now, still has technical and conceptual problems with temporal phrases and temporal quantification. For the former, problems arise both on the syntactic side (the structure of partially implicit when-clauses) and on the semantic one (how should those phrases be analyzed when playing the role of subjects and/or objects?). With respect to temporal quantification, the idea of adopting a substitutional view is an intriguing one, sometimes considered by linguists too (for more on the topic, see Lewis 1985, and Ludlow 1985). However, it seems that more work is necessary before non-referential theories of temporal phrases and temporal quantification can fully compete with those made available by referential approaches.

We close this chapter by briefly returning to the linguistic/semantical reasons the A-theorist has for dropping temporal reference. In section 4.1 it was argued that B-theories don't have the resources to account both for temporal indexicals and for sentences referring to linguistic tokens. One might wonder, in this connection, why that line of argumentation is not extended to indexicality in general, thence rejecting the referential view for objectual talk too. Problems similar to those discussed in section 4.1 for time indexicals are, in fact, found with all of the so-called essential indexicals; witness the fact that Castañeda's (1967) original observations were about the first person pronoun. Nonetheless, Ludlow, our A-theorist, does not seem willing to reject objectual reference along with temporal. Possibly this is due to the fact that he also has philosophical reasons (which we haven't discussed) for distrusting the referential view as applied to temporal talk, so that the linguistic/semantical and the philosophical/metaphysical reasons reinforce each other. Thus, linguists who might not be convinced by the above line of argumentation about temporal indexicals, because, e.g., they are willing to maintain that part of the account of indexicals be outside semantics, should nevertheless face the philosophical arguments. However, the linguistic/semantical reasons might gain in importance if it could be argued that the proper treatment of indexicality is actually as suggested in section 4.1, but there is an asymmetry between temporal and objectual talk, which motivates maintaining a referential apparatus for the latter while discarding it for the former.

Perhaps such an argument can be based on the idea that indexicality seems a much more wide-spread and fundamental phenomenon in the temporal domain than in the objectual one. Besides tenses and such terms as yesterday, tomorrow, etc., even three o’clock or February 15 are indexical (or, more generally, context dependent). The only expressions that do not seem to fall within such a generalization are those providing full specification, e.g., April 25, 2002. These too interact with tenses, though, so that there seem to be enough reasons for maintaining that indexicality/context dependence is the rule for temporal talk. If so, the linguistic/semantical argument that Ludlow deploys could be extended toward the general conclusion that indexicality always requires a non-referential, disquotational analysis (which can be complemented with a simulationist approach to propositional attitudes: see section 4.4). Those devices (almost) exhaust the requirements of temporal talk, whereas the ubiquity of non-indexical (non-context-dependent) objectual talk motivates also a referential apparatus for the latter.
